questions.question_text:
The STUDENTS table exists in your schema.
Examine the DECLARE section of a PL/SQL block:
//IMG//

Which two blocks are valid?

discussion.content: AE - is correct answer

Selected Answer: AE
AE - is correct answer, ref cursors or only sys ref cursors can be assigned value to one another not ordinary cursor to ordinary cursor or ref/sys ref cursor to ordinary cursor.

Selected Answer: AE
only A and E works
A is the only correct answer. D would have qualified if it had an "END" statement. Note that code block should be in between the BEGIN and END statements
AE is correct answer.
AE is right
AE is correct answer please check and repost the question.

I think that the correct answer is AE. 

"D" will return an "expression is of wrong type" error.
Please re-check this!
Reason: You cannot assign a value to an explicit cursor, use it in an expression. stcur is explicit cursor in our example

choices.A: BEGIN OPEN cursor3 FOR SELECT * FROM students; cursor1 :=cursor3; END;
choices.C: BEGIN OPEN cursor1 FOR SELECT * FROM students; stcur :=cursor1; END;
choices.E: BEGIN OPEN cursor1 FOR SELECT * FROM students; cursor2 :=cursor1;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct, 
B gives error due to l_rec(100,50), PLS-00308: this construct is not allowed as the origin of an assignment

A is the correct answer:
B- You cant use PL/SQL data types and record type into the USING clause;
C- Would be correct if you use in the EXECUTE IMMEDIATE statement a bind variable for the function call and if you use clause USING IN OUT; in this situation function calc_price needs an IN OUT parameter, so using EXECUTE IMMEDIATE with a call to this function without a bind variable the compiler will give an error because it cant return the result into the IN OUT variable.
D- Here the USING clause of EXECUTE IMMEDIATE its using a RECORD type wich is forbidden (as an explanation for the A answer, wich is right, is good to use a record variable wich is create under a package, because it becomes an SQL type and can be calle from an SQL enviroment)

comments.content: D isnt using a record type tho. Its using a record variable.

discussion.content: I verified in PL/SQL and ALL the sentences executes but all have error, the only who has less error is the B answer but the anonymous block has pragma error
B is correct, A is not correct because of this error (1_rec_price) it should be 1_rec.price
A is correct. l_rec(100, 50) is not a correct assignment
Correct answer is A.

comments.content: 1_rec_price must be a typo mistake in question.
Next time take time to check Your opinion. There is no posibility to use l_rec(100,50) as IN OUT param)

choices.A: CREATE PACKAGE pkg AS TYPE rec_typ IS RECORD (price NUMBER, inc_pct NUMBER); PROCEDURE calc_price (price_rec IN OUT rec_typ); END pkg; / CREATE PACAKGE BODY pkg AS PROCEDURE calc_price (price_rec IN OUT rec_typ) AS BEGIN price_rec.price := price_rec.price + (price_rec.price * price_rec.inc_pct)/100; END calc_price; END pkg; / DECLARE 1_rec pkg. rec_typ; BEGIN 1_rec_price :=100; 1_rec.inc_pct :=50; EXECUTE IMMEDIATE BEGIN pkg. calc_price (:rec); END; USING IN OUT 1_rec; END;
choices.C: CREATE PACKAGE pkg AS TYPE rec_typ IS RECORD (price NUMBER, inc_pct NUMBER); END pkg; / CREATE PROCEDURE calc_price (price_rec IN OUT pkg. rec_typ) AS BEGIN price_rec.price := price_rec.price + (price_rec.price * price_rec.inc_pct)/100; END ; / DECLARE 1_rec pkg. rec_typ; BEGIN 1_rec_price :=100; 1_rec.inc_pct :=50; EXECUTE IMMEDIATE BEGIN calc_price (1_rec); END;; END;
choices.B: CREATE PACKAGE pkg AS TYPE rec_typ IS RECORD (price NUMBER, inc_pct NUMBER); END pkg; / CREATE PROCEDURE calc_price (price_rec IN OUT pkg. rec_typ) AS BEGIN price_rec.price := price_rec.price + (price_rec.price * price_rec.inc_pct)/100; END / DECLARE 1_rec pkg.rec_typ; BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE BEGIN calc_price (:rec); END; USING IN OUT 1_rec (100, 50); END;
choices.D: DECLARE TYPE rec_typ IS RECORD (price NUMBER, inc_pct NUMBER); 1_rec rec-typ; PROCEDURE calc_price (price_rec IN OUT rec_typ) AS BEGIN price_rec.price := price-rec.price+ (price_rec.price * price_rec.inc_pct)/100; END; BEGIN 1_rec_price :=100; 1_rec.inc_pct :=50; EXECUTE IMMEDIATE BEGIN calc_price (:rec); END; USING IN OUT 1_rec;

discussion.content: A and E

Selected Answer: AE
RELIES_ON is deprecated. As of Oracle Database 12c, the database detects all data sources that are queried while a result-cached function is running, and RELIES_ON clause does nothing.
https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/lnpls/RESULT_CACHE-clause.html#GUID-7B0FFFDF-C953-46E5-9FD6-C41DFBDE1B0B

comments.content:
RELIES_ON: Specifies the data sources on which the results of the function depend. Each
data_source is the name of either a database table or view.

discussion.content:
To make a function result-cached, include the RESULT_CACHE clause in the function
definition. If you declare the function before defining it, you must also include the
RESULT_CACHE option in the function declaration.
A and E
AE is the correct answer
Why C and not E?

comments.content: I think C is incorrect since this reference says the "DETERMISTIC" clause cache isn't shared across sessions. https://www.red-gate.com/simple-talk/sql/oracle/result-cache-part-1/

questions.question_text:
Examine this function header:
FUNCTION calc_new_sal (emp_id NUMBER) RETURN NUMBER;
You want to ensure that whenever this PL/SQL function is invoked with the same parameter value across active sessions, the result is not recomputed.
If a DML statement is modifying a table which this function depends upon, the function result must be recomputed at that point in time for all sessions calling this function.
Which two actions should you perform?

choices.C: Add the deterministic clause to the function definition.
choices.D: Add the RELIES_ON clause to the function definition.
choices.E: Add the RESULT_CACHE clause to the function definition.
choices.B: Enable the result cache by using DBMS_RESULT_CACHE.BYPASS (FALSE).

discussion.content:
Correct Answer will B and F
because
limit will be 200 count will be 100 and last will be 100 and next(199) will return null.

Selected Answer: BF
B & F!

DECLARE
 TYPE va$ IS VARRAY(200) OF NUMBER;
 va va$ := va$();
BEGIN
 va.EXTEND(100);
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('count: ' || va.count); --100
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('limit: ' || va.limit); --200
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('first: ' || va.first); --1
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('last: ' || va.last); --100
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('va(1): ' || va(1)); --null
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('va(100): ' || va(100)); --null
 --DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('va(101): ' || va(101)); --ORA-06533: Subscript beyond count
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('va.next(1): ' || va.next(1)); --2
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('va.next(99): ' || va.next(99)); --100
 DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('va.next(100): ' || va.next(100)); --null
END;
/

Selected Answer: BF
As already said by the other comments
BF the right answer

choices.C: va. LIMIT and va. COUNT will return the same value.
choices.D: va. LIMIT and va. NEXT (199) will return the same value.
choices.A: va. LAST and va. LIMIT will return the same value.
choices.B: va. LAST and va. COUNT will return the same value.

verified 2 and 6, the error in 2 is PLS-00103: Encountered the symbol ")" and the 6 the error is DBMS_PUTPUT

Line 2 is wrong because new variable requires type for itself. Line 7 is wrong since collection attribute next requires as input parameter the index of existing element from which we want to find next one like this array.next(curr_index).
Line 2, line 7 -> A, E
Line 3 is fine. Line 2 needs a lot of fixing, but I suspect this question has more issues in it.
